Award.AwardTitle: Electrochemical Underpotential Co-deposition of Binary and Ternary Alloys: Towards a Novel Manufacturing Technology

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides funding to explore the advantages and investigate the fundamental limitations of a novel electrochemical process for alloy film formation, with the objective to assess its viability as a practical manufacturing technology. This process exploits the energy released upon alloy formation to predict the conditions under which a film with a predetermined composition and structure is obtained. Theoretically, this process provides complete control over material formation, but in manufacturing environments the predictive capabilities of this method are limited by the need to achieve sufficiently fast production rates. Experiments with a set of binary alloys will therefore quantify how and to what extent practical production rates will affect the theoretical predictions, ideally providing correction terms that will enable one to maintain process control under practical manufacturing conditions. Fast production rates also hinder the direct synthesis of complex crystal structures of technological interest; formation of such structures will be therefore investigated by tailoring the synthesis conditions, to inhibit the formation of alternative structures. Finally, this process will be extended to alloy materials composed of three elements.

If successful, the results of this research will strongly impact current practices in manufacturing processes utilizing alloy films, in particular microfabrication processes, by providing a robust and precise method for the synthesis of new materials, using procedures characterized by low cost and low energetic impact. In particular, new processes for the formation of platinum- and palladium-based alloys will be made available, which may provide enhanced performance in magnetic or energy conversion devices. Other potential benefits include a simplification of current manufacturing processes and the development of new device concepts that may exploit materials made available through this research.

Institution.Name: University of Virginia Main Campus
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

POR.DRECONTENT:
Electrodeposition is a film growth process whereby metal ions are reduced from an electrolyte and deposited at a conductive substrate to form metals or alloys. Alloy composition determines its properties and potential applications, and is usually controlled by the rate of arrival of ions at the substrate, which depends on difficult to control electrolyte flow and convective effects. An alternative solution to precisely control alloy composition involves the strength of interaction between the depositing ions.

An alloy A-B owe its stability to the strong interactions between different atoms; this same interactions can be exploited in the electrodeposition process to induce the deposition of an atom B when an atom A is present at the surface; this process at very low deposition rates is described by precise energetic relationship, allowing prediction of the alloy composition as a function of the growth conditions.

This project explores the extent to which these predictions are valid and investigate what would happen if they are not. In brief, alloys that exhibit a strong attractive interaction obey these energetic predictions, and the composition can be predetermined from data available for bulk alloys, under the condition that the deposition is close to being reversible. More complex systems, forming different crystal structures at distinct composition, may experience energetic barriers for the formation of the new structure, and the range of stability of this structure is shifted with respect to the bulk alloy. Most interestingly, the microstructure of alloys made of elements that do not mix is strongly dependent on the growth rate; under these conditions a variety of micro/nanostructures have been observed, with the potential of exhibiting unusual properties.

This effort reformulates and generalizes the thermodynamic and kinetic principles of alloy electrodeposition, detailing the predicted crystal structure and microstructure for various classes of alloys and comparing predictions with experimental results. These comparisons allow to determine the optimum trade-off between the need to control alloy composition and structure against the practical limitations involved in realistic manufacturing processes. Additionally, these findings elicit a better understanding of the interplay between macroscopic thermodynamic concepts and atomistic kinetic processes in determining the growth and structure of electrodeposited alloys.

From the technological standpoint, the availability of novel alloy deposition processes and improved alloy films will advance industrial microfabrication processes, leading to innovation in electrodeposition science and technology in general. This project has also made possible the overhaul of a graduate class in materials electrochemistry, which has facilitated the teaching of several short courses for graduate students and professionals. One of the graduate students has carried out an internship with IBM, transitioning to an occupation after defending his dissertation.

 


Last Modified: 12/18/2016
Modified by: Giovanni Zangari

Image
  • Underpotential codeposition consists in inducing deposition of a metal B when a metal A is present at the surface. The process is enabled by an attractive interaction between A-B, shifting in the positive direction the deposition of B according to precise energetic relationships.
    Giovanni Zangari
    Copyrighted
    Giovanni Zangari
    Composition prediction in underpotential codeposition
